metadata.name: Comprehensive Language Assessment - Example Questions
metadata.description: 10 redesigned questions demonstrating contextualized production approach
designPrinciples: Distractor chips test common mistakes (NOT hints via clustering)
Randomized chip positions (correct answer varies position)

phases.name: A1 - Beginner
phases.description: Basic communication, present tense, essential vocabulary

phases.name: B1 - Intermediate
phases.description: Complex grammar, spatial/temporal expressions, nuanced meaning

questions.scenario: You're introducing your friend Maria at a party. She's from Brazil.
questions.question: How do you describe Maria's nationality?
questions.teachingNote: Nationality uses SER (permanent identity) not ESTAR (temporary state). Correct answer at position 2 (randomized).

questions.scenario: Your friend Paulo calls you every morning before work to chat.
questions.en: Paulo talks with me every day
questions.question: Complete the sentence:
questions.teachingNote: Third person singular present: falar → fala. Tests agreement with 'Paulo' (he). Correct answer at position 3.

questions.question: Complete the sentence:
questions.teachingNote: Quick check of basic article agreement. No scenario needed for fundamental grammar. Correct answer at position 2.

questions.scenario: You're telling your colleague about your weekend. Yesterday you visited your parents in São Paulo.
questions.question: Complete your story:
questions.teachingNote: Preterite (simple past) for completed actions. 'Ontem' signals preterite, not imperfect. Correct answer at position 2.

questions.scenario: You're reminiscing about your childhood. Every summer, your family would travel to the beach.
questions.en: We traveled to the beach every summer
questions.question: Describe your childhood habit:
questions.template: Nós ______ para a praia todo verão
questions.teachingNote: Imperfect for habitual past actions. 'Todo verão' signals repetition, not one-time event. Correct answer at position 2.

questions.question: Complete the sentence:
questions.teachingNote: Standard comparative structure. This tests if student knows 'mais...do que' pattern. Correct answer at position 2.

questions.scenario: You're at a café with your friend Ana. There are three men: one at your table, one at Ana's table (a few meters away), and one across the street outside.
questions.en: That man (across the street) is a teacher
questions.question: Point to the man far from both of you and say:
questions.hint: far from both speaker and listener
questions.teachingNote: Three-way demonstrative system: este (near me), esse (near you), aquele (far from both). Context is crucial. NO CLUSTERING: only one from each demonstrative category. Correct answer at position 2.

questions.scenario: Your friend is studying medicine. She studies every night because she wants to become a doctor.
questions.en: She studies to become a doctor
questions.question: Express her purpose:
questions.teachingNote: PARA = purpose/goal ('in order to'). POR = reason/cause. This is a classic distinction error. Correct answer at position 2.

questions.question: Complete the sentence:
questions.teachingNote: Simple future tense. 'Amanhã' clearly signals future. Correct answer at position 2.

questions.scenario: Your friend Pedro is always late. You're meeting him for dinner tonight and you're worried he'll be late again.
questions.en: I hope he arrives on time
questions.question: Express your hope:
questions.teachingNote: Present subjunctive triggered by 'espero que' (doubt/desire). Real-world scenario makes the doubt/uncertainty concrete. Correct answer at position 2.

questions.scenario: Your friend is frustrated with her job. She says 'If I had more money, I would quit and travel the world.' You want to respond with your own hypothetical.

steps.question: Complete the consequence:
steps.template: Se eu fosse rico, eu ______ mais
steps.fullSentence: Se eu fosse rico, eu viajaria mais

questions.teachingNote: Multi-step tests both parts of hypothetical: imperfect subjunctive (if clause) + conditional (result). Shows complete sentence construction ability. EACH STEP HAS ITS OWN CHIPS. Step 1 answer is locked in before Step 2 appears.

chipSelectionRules.rule1: NO CLUSTERING: Avoid multiple variations of the correct answer that hint at the answer category
chipSelectionRules.badExample: chips: [Aquele, Esse, Este, O, Um, Daquele, Naquele, Aquilo] ← 4 aquele-related = hint!
chipSelectionRules.goodExample: chips: [Aquele, Esse, Este, O, Algum, Outro, Cada, Qual] ← only one from each category
chipSelectionRules.rule2: RANDOMIZE POSITIONS: Correct answer should appear at different positions (0-7), not always first
chipSelectionRules.rule3: TEST COMMON ERRORS: Include chips that represent typical mistakes
commonErrors: Wrong person (eu form instead of ele/ela)
chipSelectionRules.rule4: BALANCE: Mix obviously wrong options with subtle errors
chipSelectionRules.balanceExample: trabalharei (correct), trabalho (wrong tense), trabalharia (wrong mood), trabalhar (infinitive), xyz (nonsense)

multiStep.format: Scenario → Step 1 (with chips) → Step 2 (with chips) → (Optional Step 3)
mechanics: EACH STEP has its own chips array
User answers Step 1, selects from chips
Step 1 answer is LOCKED IN (displayed in Step 2 template)
Step 2 shows new template with Step 1 answer filled in
User answers Step 2, selects from NEW chips
characteristics: Shows ability to combine grammar points

step2.template: Se eu fosse rico, eu ______ mais

example.result: Se eu fosse rico, eu viajaria mais
